All I ask is that you have a true and proper understanding.
"Followers of the Way,
even if you can understand a hundred sutras and treatises,
you're not as good as one plain monk who does nothing.
As soon as you acquire a little of such understanding,
you start treating others with scorn and contempt,
vying and struggling with them like so many asuras,
blinded by the ignorance of self and others,
forever creating karma that will send you to hell.
You're like the monk Good Star
who understood all the twelve divisions of the teaching
but fell into hell alive,
the earth unwilling tolerate him.
Better to do nothing, to leave off all that.
When you get hungry, eat your rice;
when you get sleepy, close your eyes.
Fools may lough at me,
but wise men will know what I mean.
"Followers of the Way,
don't search for anything in written words.
The exertions of your mind wi8ll tire it out, you'll gulp cold air and gain nothing.
Better to realize that at every moment all is conditioned and without true birth,
to go beyond the bodhisattvas of the Three Vehicle provisional doctrines.
"Fellow believers,
don't dawdle your days away!
In the past, before I had come to see things right,
there was nothing but blackness all around me.
But I knew that I shouldn't let the time slip by in vain,
and so, belly on afire, mind in a rush,
I raced all over in search of the Way.
Later I was able to get help from others,
so that finally I could do as I'm doing today,
talking with you followers of the Way.
As followers of the Way, let me urge you
not to do what you are doing just for the sake of clothing and food.
See how quickly th world goes by!
A good friend and teacher is hard to find,
as rarely met with as the udumbara flower.
"You've heard here and there that there's this old fellow Linji, and so you come here
intending to confront him in debate
and push him to the point where he can't answer.
But when I come at students like that with my whole body,
their eyes are wide open enough
but their mouths can't utter a word.
Dumbfounded, they have no idea how to answer me.
Then I say top them,
'The trampling of a bull elephant is more than a donkey can stand!'
"You go all around pointing to your chest,
puffing out your sides, saying:
'I understand Chan! I understand the Way!'
But when two or three turn up here,
you're completely helpless. For shame! With that body and mind of yours
you go around everywhere flapping two lips,
hoodwinking the village people,
but the day will come when you'll taste the rion cudgels of hell!
You're not men who have left the household -
you belong, all of you, in the realm of the asuras!
"The ultimate principles that make up the Way
are not something to be thrashed out in contentious debate,
clanging and banging to beat down the unbeliwevers.
This thing handed down from the buddhas and patriarchs
has no special meaning.
It if were put in the form of verbal teachings,
it would sink to the level of the teaching categories, the Three Vehicles,
the five natures, the conditions leading to birth as human and heavenly beings.
But the teaching of the sudden and immediate enlightenment is not like that.
The Bodhisattva Good Treasures never went around searching anywhere.
"Fellow believers,
do not use your minds in a mistaken manner,
but be like the sea that rejects the bodies of the dead.
While you continue to carry such dead bodies and go racing around the world with them,
you only obstruct your own vision and create obstacles in your mind.
When no clouds block the sun, the beautiful light of heaven shines everywhere.
When no disease afflicts the eye, it does not see phantom flowers in the empty air.
"Followers of the Way,
if you wish to be always in accord with the Dharma,
never give way to doubt,
'Spread it out and it fills the whole Dharma-realm,
gather it up and it's tinier than a thread of hair.'
Its lone brightness gleaming forth, it has never lacked anything.
'The eye doesn't see it, the ear doesn't hear it.'
What shall we call this thing?
A man of old said:
'Say something about a thing and you're already off the mark.'
But there's no end to this talk. (See/find out for yourself! [CA])
(what's there in addition? [CA])
Each of you, do your best! Thank you for your trouble."
"I'm only afraid it's not enough!"
said the monk.
Huangbo immediately struck him a blow.
The monk mentioned the incident to the Master.
The master said:
"For your sake I'll put this old fellow to the test!"
As soon as the Master had gone to Huangbo's quarters and was standing in attendance by him,
Huangbo mentioned his earlier conversation with the monk in charge of cooking rice.
The Master said:
"The monk didn't understand.
I hope, Reverend, you'll be good enough to take his place and give us a turning word."
(83) Then the Master said:
"Isn't that too much rice?"
Huangbo said:
"Why not say, 'Tomorrow you'll have a taste of it!'?"
The Master said:
"Why say 'tomorrow?'
Have a taste of it right now!"
As soon as he had finished speaking, he gave Huangbo a slap.
Huangbo said:
"This raving idiot,
coming in here again and pulling the tiger's whiskers!"
The Master gave a shout and left the room.
Later Weishan asked Yangshan,
"What were those two worthy gentlemen up to?"
Yangshan said:
"What do you think, Reverend?"
Weishan said:
"When you bring up a son, you begin to understand a father's kindness."
Yangshan said: "That's not it!"
Weishan said:
"Well, what do you think?"
Yangshan said:
"It's just like bringing home a thief and losing everything in the house." (joining a villain in ravaging one's home [CA])
The Master asked a monk:
"Where did you come from?"
The monk gave a shout.
The Master bowed slightly and motioned for him to sit down.
The monk was about to say something,
whereupon the Master struck him a blow.
The Master saw a monk coming and held his fly whisk straight up.
The monk made a low bow, whereupon the Master struck him a blow
The Master sawd another monk coming and again held his fly whisk straight up.
The monk paid no attention,
whereupon the Master struck him a blow as well.
One day the Master went with Puhua to eat a meal at the home of a lay believer.
The Master said:
"One hair swallows up the huge sea; one mustard seed holds Mount Sumeru.

Is this a manifestation of supernatural power, or is it just the way things have always been?" (one has make here a contrast between 用 'function' and 體 'essence', so the trans. does not get the point [CA])

Puhua said:

The following day the Master once again went with Puhua

One day the Master was sitting with Heyang and Muta, to elderly monks
around the fire pit in the dirt -floored part of the monk's hall.
Someone took the opportunity to remark,
"Puhua goes around the streets of town every day behaving like an idiot or a madman.
I can't tell whether he's a common mortal or a sage."
Before the speaker had finished,
Puhua came in.
The Master said:
"Are you a common mortal or a sage?"
Puhua said:
"You tell me,
am I a common mortal or a sage?"
The Master gave a shout.
Puhua pointed with his finger and said:
"Heyang is a new bride,
Muta is an old Chan granny.
Linji is a little brat,
but he's got an eye!"
The Master said: "This thief!"
Puhua said: "Thief! Thief!"
and left the hall.
One day Puhua was in front of the monks' hall eating raw vegetables.
The Master saw him and said:
"Exactly like a donkey!"
Puhua brayed like a donkey.
The Master said: "This thief!"
Puhua said: "Thief! Thief!"
and walked away.
Puhua regularly went around the streets of the town ringing a hand bell and saying:
"Come on the bright side and I hit you on the bright side.
Come on the dark side and I'll hit you on the dark side.
Come from four corners or eight directions and I'll hit you like a whirlwind.
Come from the empty sky and I'll hit you like so many flails."
Because of this, the Master instructed his attendant to go and,
as soon as Puhua had spoken in this way,
to grab hold of him and say,
"What will you do when I don't come in any of those ways?"
When the attendant had done so, Puhua pushed him away and said:
"Tomorrow there's to be a meal at the Great Compassion Cloister."
The attendant came back and reported this to the Master.
The Master said:
"For some time now I've been suspicious of this fellow!"
An elderly monk came for an interview with the Master.
Before he had finished with the customary greetings, he asked:
"Would it be right to make a formal bow?
Or would it be right to do without the bow?"
The Master gave a shout.
The elderly monk made a formal bow.
The Master said:
"Quite some thief-in-the-grass!"
The elderly monk said: "Thief! Thief!"
and left the room.
The Master said:
"Better not think that that ends the matter!"
The head monk was standing in attendance.
The Master said:
"Were there any mistakes or not?"
The head monk said: "There were."
The Master said:
"Was the guest mistaken? Or was the host mistaken?"
The head monk said:
"Both were mistaken?"
The Master said: "Where was the mistake?"
The head monk left the room.
The Maste said:
"Better not think that that ends the matter!"
Later a monk mentioned the incident to Nanquan.
Nanquan said:
"Government horses trampling on each o
The Master was entering an army encampment to attend a dinner
when he saw one of the officers at the gate.
He pointed to the bare wooden gatepost and said:
"A common mortal or a sage?"
The officer had no reply.
The Master struck the gatepost and said:
"Even if you managed a reply, it would still just a wooden post!"
With that he entered the camp.
The Master said to the director of temple business,
"Where have you been?"
The director said:
"I have been to the district office to sell glutinous rice."
The Master said:
"Did you sell all of it?"
The director said:
"Yes, I sold all of it."
The Master took his staff and drew a mark on the ground in front of him and said:
"Can you sell this too?"
The driector gave a shout.
The Master hit him.
When the supervisor of meals happened along,
the Mastesr mentnioned his earlier exchange.
(90) The supervisor of meals said:
"The director didn't understand your meaning, Reverend."
The Master said:
"What about you?"
The supervisor made a long bow.
the Master hit him too.
A study director came to see the Master.
The Master said:
"Study Director, what sutras or treatises are you lecturing on these days?"
The study director replied.
"I'm a man of limited abilities,
which I'm at present applying to the study of the Treatise on the Hundred Dharmas."
The Master said:
"Suppose there were one man who understood the Three Vehicles
and the twelve divisions of the teachings,
and another man who didn't understand the Three Vehicles
and the twelve divisions of the teachings.
Would they be the same of different?"
The study director said:
"In understanding they would be the same.
In not understanding they would be different."
Lepu,
who at the time was standing in attendance behind the Master, said:
(91) "Study Director, what kind of place do you take this for,
talking of same and different!"
The Master turned his head and asked the attendant,
"What do you think?"
The attendant gave a shout.
When the Master had returned from seeing off the study director,
he said to the attendant,
"Was it me you shouted at a moment ago?"
The attendant said: "Yes."
The Master struck him a blow.
The Master learned that the second Deshan was telling his students,
"If you can speak, it's thrity blows,
and if you can't speak, it's thrity blows!"
The Master intructed Lepu, saying, "Go to his place and ask,
'If I can speak, why do I get thirty blows?'
When he hits you,
grab his stick, give him a jab,
and see what he does then.'
When Lepu arrived at Deshan's place, he followed the Master's instructions and asked the question.
Deshan hit him,
whereupon he grabbed his stick and gave Deshan a jab.
Deshan returned to his quarters.
Lepu went back and reported to the Master what had happened.
The Master said:
"For some time now I have been suspicious of this fellow!
But however that may be,
did you really get to see Deshan?"
When Lepu was about to argue about that,
the Master hit him.
On day Constant Attendant Wang called on the Master
and together they went to look at the monk's hall.
Constant Attendant Wang said:
"This hallful of monks - do they read sutras perhaps?"
The Master said:
"No, they don't read sutras."
"Do they perhaps learn how to meditate?"
asked the Constant Attendant.
"No, they don't learn how to meditate."
said the Master.
The Constant Attendant said:
"If they don't read sutras and they don't learn how to meditate,
what in fact do they do?"
The Master said:
"We're training all of them to become buddhas and patriarchs."
The Constant Attendant said:
"Gold dust may be precious, but if it gets in the eye it can blind.
What about it?"
The Master said:
"And I always thought you were just an ordinary fellow!"
The Master said to Xingshan:
"How about that white ox on the bare ground?"
Xingshan said: "Moo, moo!"
The Master said: "Lost your voice?"
Xingshan said:
"How about you, Reverend?"
The Master said:
"This beast!"
The Master said to Lepu:
"Up to now, one man has used the stick, and another has used the shout.
Which gets closer to it?"
Lepu said:
"Neither gets close to it!"
The Master said:
"Then how would you get close to it?"
Lepu gave a shout.
The Master struck him.
The Master saw a monk approaching
and opened both hands and held them out.
The monk said nothing.
The Master understand: "Do you understand?"
The monk said: "No, I don't."
The Master said:
"This Kunlun can't be broken open!
Here's two coins for you."
Dajue came to the Master for an interview.
The Master held his fly whisk upright.
Dajue spread his sitting cloth in preparation for a formal bow.
The Master threw down his fly whisk.
Dajue folded up his sitting cloth and went to the monks' hall.
The other monks said:
"This monk must be an old friend of the Reverend, don't you suppose?
(96) He doesn't make a formal bow, and he doesn't get a taste of the stick either!"
The Master, hearing of this, had Dajue summoned.
When Dajue appeared,
the Master said:
"The monks in my group are saying
you haven't greeted me yet."
Dajue said: "How are you?"
Then he returned and joined the other monks.
When Zhaozhou was traveling around, he came for an interview with the Master.
The Master was just then washing his feet.
Zhaozhou asked:
"What did the Patriarch have in mind when he came from the west?"
The Master said:
"As it happens, I'm just now washing my feet."
Zhaozhou came close and made as though listening.
The Master said:
"All right then, I'll throw out a second dipperful of dirty water!"
With that Zhaozhou turned and left.
A certain distinguished monk named Ding came to the Master for an interview
and asked: "What is the basic meaning of Buddhism?"
The Master got down from his chair, grabbed hold of him and gave him a slap.
Then he let him go.
Ding stood in a daze.
A monk standing nearby said:
"Mr. Ding, why don't you make a bow?"
As Ding was making a formal bow,
he suddenly had a great enlightenment.
Mayu came for an interview with the Master.
He spread his sitting cloth and asked:
"In the case of the twelve-faced Guanyin,
which face in the real one?"
The Master got down from his corded chair.
With one hand he snatched up the sitting cloth
and with the other he seized hold of Mayu and said:
"The twelve-faced Guanyhin -
where'd it go to?"
Mayu twisted himself free and tried to sit down in the corded chair.
The Master picked up his stick and hit him.
Mayu grabbed the stick and, each holding to one end it, they went off to the Master's quarters.
"At times my shout is like the precious sword of the Diamond King.
At times my shout is like a golden-haired lion crouching on the ground.
At times my shout is like the search pole and the shadow grass.
At times my shout doesn't work like a shout at all.
Do you understand?"
The monk started to answer,
whereupon the Master gave a shout.
The Master said to a nun:
"Well come, or ill come?"
The nun gave a shout.
The Master picked up his stick and said:
"Speck then, speak!"
The nun shouted once more.
The Master struck her.
Longya asked:
"What did the Patriarch have in mind when he came from the west?"
The Master said:
"Hand me the meditation board, please."
Longya handed the meditation board to the Master.
The Master took it and hit Longya with it.
Longya said:
"As far as hitting goes, you can hit me all right.
But that's still not what the Patriarch had in mind."
Later Longya arrived at Cuiwei's place and asked:
"What did the Patriarch have in mind when he came from the west?"
Cuiwei said:
"Hand me the cushion, please."
Longya handed the cushion to Cuiwei.
Cuiwei took it and hit Longya with it.
Longya said:
"As far as hitting goes, you can hit me all right.
But that's still not what the Patriarch had in mind."
Later, when Longya had settled down in a temple,
a monk came to his room and requested special instruction, saying:
"When you were traveling from place to place
Reverend, I've heard about how you had interviews with those two worthy old gentlemen.
Do you approve of what they did or don't you?"
Longya said:
"As for as approving goes, I approve completely.
But that's still not what the Patriarch had in mind."
Jingshan had a group of five hundred monks under him
but few of them went for an interview and instruction.
Huangbo instructed the Master to go to Jingshan's palce.
Then he said:
"What do you intend to do when you get there?"
The Master said:
"When I get there I'll think of some expedient."
The Master arrived at Jingshan's place.
Still dressed in his travling clothes, he entered the Dharma Hall to see Jingshan.
Jingshan had no sooner raised his head
than the Master have a shout.
Jingshan made as though to open his mouth.
The Master shook out his sleeves and left.
One of the monks questioned Jinghsan, saying:
"This monk just now - what sort of words of instruction did you give him
that he shouted at you, Reverend?"
Jingshan said:
"This monk came from Huangbo's group.
If you want to know,
go ask him yourself."
Of Jingshan's five hundred monks, over half left him and went elsewhere.
One day Puhua went around the streets of the town
begging people to give him a one-piece robe.
But though people offered him one,
he refused all their offers.
The Master sent the director of temple business out to buy of coffin.
When Puhua returned to the temple
the Master said:
"If have prepared this one-piece robe for you!"
Puhua shouldered the coffin and went off with it.
He threaded his way through the streets of the town, calling out,
"Linji has prepared a one-piece robe for me!
I'm going to the east gate to take leave of the world!"
The townspeople trooped after him, eager to see what would happen.
Puhua said:
"I'm not going to do it today.
But tomorrow I'll go to the south gate and take leave of the world!"
He did this for three days,
till no one believed him anymore.
Then, on the fourth day, when no one was following or watching him,
he went alone outside the city wall, lay down in the coffin,
and asked a passerby to nail on the lid.
In no time, word of this spread abroad
and the townspeople came scrambling. But when they opened the coffin,
they found that all trace of his body had vanished.
They could just cathch the echo of his hand bell sounding sharp and clear in the sky before it faded away.

div.head:
行錄
Record of Activities (PART FOUR)

p.seg: The head monk said:
"Have you been in to question the teacher yet?"
The Master said:
"No, I haven't been in to ask the questions.
I don't know what to ask."
The head monk said:
"Why don't you go ask the Reverend who heads this temple:
'What is the real basic meaning of the Buddha-dharma?'"
The Master went and asked,
but before he had finished speaking, Huangbo struck him a blow.
When the Master returned from the interview,
the head monk said:
"How did the question go?"
The Master said:
"Before I had even finished asking the question,
the Reverend struck me.
I don't understand."
The head monk said:
"Just go ask him again."
(105) The Masterd went and asked again,
and again Huangbo hit him.
In this way he went three times to ask his question
and three times was struck.
The Master came to report to the head monk:
"Thanks to your kind instruction,
I've been able to question the Reverend.
Three times I questioned him and three times he struck me.
To my regret, I'm impeded by bad karma and can't grasp the profound meaning I all this.
Now I'll going on my way."
The head monk said:
"If you're going,be sure to take leave of the Reverend."
The Master bowed low and withdrew.
The head monk went to see Huangbo before the Master could do so and said:
"That young monk who came to question you
has a lot of good sense.
I hope you'll help him along.
Later I'm sure he'll shape up into a fine big tree
that will make cool shape for the people of the world."
When the Master came to take his leave,
Huangbo said:
"You mustn't think of going anywhere else
just go to Dayu's place by the river rapids in Gaoan.
He will surely explain things for you."
When the Master arrived at Dayu's place,
Dayu asked:
"Where have you come from?"
The Master said:
"I've come from Huangbo's place."
Dayu said:
"Did Huangbo have any wordes or phrases to teach you?"
The Master said:
"I asked him three times what is the real basic meaning of the Buddha-dharma,
and three times I was struck.
I don't know whether I did something wrong or not."
Dayu said:
(106) wearing himself out on your account,
and then you come here and ask whether you did something wrong or not!"
At these words, the Master experienced a great enlightenment. He said:
"There really wasn't anything so hard about Huangbo's Buddha-dharma after all!"
Dayu seized hold of him and said:
"This little bed-wetting devil!
A minute ago asking if you did something wrong,
and now you say there's nothing so hard about Huangbo's Buddha-dharma!
What kind of truth do you think you've spied?
Out with it! Out with it!"
The Master punched Dayu three times in the ribs with his fist.
Dayu let go of him and said:
"Your teacher is Huangbo.
You're no business of mine!"
The Master took leaved of Dayu
and returned to Huangbo.
When Huangbo saw him coming, he said:
"This fellow coming and going, coming and going - when will he ever have done with it?"
The Master said:
"And it's all because of your grandmotherly kindness!"
Then, when he had finished the customary greetings, he went and stood in attendance by Huangbo.
Huangbo said:
"Where have you been?"
The Master said:
"Following your kind instructions the other day,
I went to visit Dayu."
Huangbo said:
"Did Dayu have any words or phrases for you?"
The Master then related the conversation that had taken place between Dayu and himself.
Huangbo said:
"If only I could get my hands on that fellow right now - I'd give him a real wallop!"
(107) The Master said:
"What's that you say you'll do?"
You can taste this right now!"
With that he gave Huangbo a slap.
Huangbo said:
"This raving idiot,
coming back here and pulling the tiger's whiskers!"
The Master gave a shout.
Huangbo said:
"Attendant, drag this raving idiot out of here and take him to the monks' hall!"
Later Weishan related this incident and asked Yangshan,
"At that time, was Linji indebted to Dayu,
or was he indebted to Huangbo?"
Yangshan said:
"He not only rode on the tiger's head,
but he got to tweak the tiger's tail as well."
The Master was planting pines
when Huangbo asked:
"Why are you planting so many of them way off here in the mountains?"
The Master said:
"First, to improve the appearance of the timple grounds.
Second, to mark the road for people who come after."
When he had finished speaking, he took up his grub hoe and hacked at the ground three times
(108) Huangbo said:
"That may be,
but you've already tasted thirty blows of my stick!"
Again the Master took his hoe and hacked at the ground three times,
blowing out his breath with a loud noise.
Huangbo said:
"When my teaching line passes along to you, it will prosper greatly in the world."
Later Weishan mentioned these worlds to Yangshan and said:
"At that time, was Huangbo entrusting his teaching line to Linji alone,
or did he have someone else in mind.?"
Yangshan said: "There was someone else.
But it was someone asso far in the futrue
that I'd hesitate to mention it to you, Reverend."
Weishan said:
"That may be so,
but I still like to know about it.
Just try telling me what you can."
Yangshan said:
"The ruler points south and his commands are obeyed in Wu and Yue.
But when they encounter the great wind, they cease."
(A prophesy concerning Reverend Fengxue.)
The Master was standing in attendance at Deshan's side.
Deshan said:
"I'am tired today!"
The Master said:
What's this old fellow doing talking in his sleep?"
Deshan struck the Master a blow.
The Master grabbed the chair Deshan was sitting on and turned it over.
Deshan let the matter end there.
The Master was out working with the other monks hoeing the fields
when he saw Huangbo coming.
Using his grub hoe for a stuff, he stood leaning on it.
Huangbo said:
"This old fellow's tired, eh?"
The Master said:
"I haven't even lifted up my hoe -
why should I be tired?"
Huangbo struck him a blow.
The Master grabbed hold of Huangbo's stick
an d gave it a shove, knocking him over.
Huangbo called to the weina:
"Weina, help me up!"
The weina came forward to help him.
"Reverend," he said, "why do you put up with such rudeness from this raving idiot?"
As soon as Huangbo got to his feet, he struck the weina a blow.
(110) The Master, hoeing the ground, said:
"Other places they cremate them,
but at our place we bury them all alive!"
Later Weishan asked Yangshan:
"When Huangbo hit the weina, what was that about?"
Yangshan said:
"When the real thief runs away, the man who was chasing him gets walloped." (lit. the person inspecting the footprints [CA])
One day the Master was sitting in meditation in front of the monks' hall
when he saw Huangbo coming.
Immediately he shut his eyes.
Huangbo made as though he were frightened
and then returned to his living quarters.
The Master followed him to his quarters and apologized.
The head monk was standing in attendance at Huangbo's side.
Huangbo said:
"This monk may be young,
but he understands about this business!"
The head monk said:
"Old Reverend, you must not have your feet on the ground
if you give your approval to this young fellow!"
Huangbo gave himself a slap on the mouth.
The head monk said:
"As long as you understand, it's all right."
The Master was in the monks' hall sleepin
Huangbo came in to look around
and rapped on the meditation platform with his stick.
The Master raised his head, but when he saw it was Huangbo, he went back to sleep.
Huangbo rapped again on the platform
and then went to the upper part of the hall.
There he saw the head monk sitting in meditation. He said:
"That young monk in the lower hall is sitting in meditation.
What are you doing here lost in daydreams!"
The head monk said:
"This old fellow - what's he up to!"
Huangbo rapped on the platform
and then left the hall.
Later Weishan asked Yangshan:
"When Huangbo came into the monks' hall, what was all that about?"
Yangshan said:
"Two winners in one throw."
One day the group was going out to work in the fields, ??
the Master walked along behind.
Huangbo turned his head and, seeing the Master empty-handed, asked:
"Where's your grup hoe?"
The Master said:
"Somebody when off with it."
Huang said:
"Come over here.
I want to work this matter out with you."
The Master went over to where he was.
Huangbo stood his hoe upright and said:
"When it comes to this,
no one in the world can take hold of it and lift it up."
The Master proceeded to grab the hoe in this hand and stand it upright.
"Then what's it doing in my hand?" he said.
Huangbo said:
"Today there was somebody who did a good day's work." (??)
Then he went back to the monastery.
Later Weishan asked Yangshan:
"If the hoe was in Huangbo's hand,
how could it have been snatched away by Linji?"
Yangshan said:
"The thief's a petty fellow, but clever beyond his betters."
The Master was sent by Huangbo to deliver a letter to Weishan's place.
At that time Yangshan was in charge of receiving visitors.
After taking the letter, he said:
"That is Huangbo's.
Now where is yours?"
The Master gave him a slap.
Yangshan seized hold of his hand and said:
"Brother, if you know that much, that ends the matter."
Together they went in to see Weishan.
Weishan asked:
"How many monks has my borther Huangbo?"
The Master said:
"Seven hundred monks."
Weishan said:
"Who is the leader among them?"
The Master said:
"He handed a letter to you just now!"
Then the Master asked Weishan:
"Reverend, how many monks do you have here?"
Weishan said:
"Fifteen hundred monks."
The Master said:
That' s a lot!"
Weishan said:
"Brother Huangbo has quite a few too."
When the Master took his leave of Weishan,
Yangshan escorted him out of the room and said:
"If later you go to the north, you'll find a place to live."
The Master said:
"Why should that be?"
Yangshan said:
"Just go. Later there will be a man who will surely help you, brother.
But the man - he'll have a head but no tail,
a beginning but no end."
Later, when the Master arrived in Zhenzhou,
he found that Puhua was already living there.
When the Master began teaching,
Puhua assisted him.
But before the Master had lived there for long,
Puhua took leave of the world, body and all.
The Master came to Huangbo's place in the middle of the summer session.
There he saw Huangbo reading sutras.
The Master said:
"I thought you must be quite some person.
But now I find you're just an old reverend who munches on black beans!"
After staying a few days, the Master prepared to take leave.
Huangbo said:
"You broke the rules by coming in the summer.
Now you're going to leave without finishing out the session?"
The Master said:
"I just came for a short time to pay my respects, Reverend."
Huangbo struck him a blow and drove him out.
After the Master had gone a few miles,
he began to have doubts about this matter,
so he went back and finished out the summer session.
One day the Master came to take leave of Huangbo.
Huangbo asked:
"Where will you go?"
The Master said:
"If not Henan, then I'll go back to Hebei."
Huangbo struck him.
The Master grabbed Huangbo's arm and slapped him with the palm of his hand.
Huangbo gave a lond laugh
and then called to his attendant:
"Bring Master Baizhang's meditation board and arm-rest!"
The Master said: "Attendant, bring me some fire!"
Huangbo said:
"You're right, of course.
But take them with you anyway.
Later on, you can use them to sit on the tongues of the men of the world!"
Later Weishan questionede Yangshan about this.
"Did Linji betray Huangbo's expectations or not?" (Did'nt Linji disgrace Huangbo? [CA])
Yangshan said: "No, he didn't."
Weishan said:
"What do you think?"
Yangshan said:
"Once you understand your obligations, you'll know how to repay them."
Weishan said:
"Were there any cases like this among the men of old times."
Yangshan said: "There were.
But it happened so long ago in the past
that I'd hesitate to mention it to you, Revered."
Weishan said:
"That may be so,
but I'd still like to know.
Just tell me what you can.
Yangshan said:
"At the gathering where the Buddha preached the Shuramgama Sutra, Ananda praised him,
saying:
'You take this profound mind and present it to all the numberless lands of the universe.
This is what is called repaying the obligations of the Buddha!'
Isn't this an example of how to repay obligations?"
"You're right, you're right!"
said Weishan.
"When onc's understanding in only equal to that his teacher, he diminishes the teacher's merit by half.
Only when one's understanding surpasses that of his teacher is he worthy of carrying on the line."
The Master arrived at Bodhidharma's memorial tower.
The keeper of the tower said:
"Will Your Reverence bow first to the Buddha, or first to the Patriarch?"
The Master said:
"I will not bow to the Buddha, or to the Patriarch either."
The keeper of the tower said:
"Has Your Reverence some grudge against the Buddha?"
The Master shook out his sleeves and left.
When the Master was traveling around ono foot, he came to Longguang's place.
Longguang ascended the hall to lecture.
The Master stepped forward and asked:
"Without unsheathing a weapon, how is it possible to win?"
Longguang straightened up in his seat. (Longguang sat on his heels; sat squatingly ?? [CA])
The Master said:
"My great good friend, surely you're not without some means to help me!"
Longguang, his eyes glaring, sighed loudly.
The Master pointed a finger at him and said:
"Old Fellow, you certainly lost out today!"
When the Master arrived at Sanfeng,
Reverend Ping asked:
"Where have you come from?"
"From Huangpo,"
the Master said.
Ping said:
"What kind of words and phrases did Huangbo have for you?"
The Master said:
"The golden ox last night fell into the furnace.
Since then no one's seen a trace of it."
Ping said:
"In the golden wind of autumn he blows a jade flute.
But who is it that understands the tune?"
The Master said:
"He passed right through the ten-thousandfold barrier,
doesn't even linger in the pure heights of heaven."
Ping said:
"Your query is far too lofty!"
The Master said:
"A dragon gave birth to a golden phoenix
that smashed through the turquoise of the sky."
Ping said:
"Sit down a while a drink you tea."
Later he asked:
"Where else have you been recently?"
The Master said: "Longguang."
Ping said:
"How is Longkuang these days?"
The Master got up and left.
When the Master arrived at Daci's place,
Daci was sitting in his quaters.
The Master said:
"When you sit up straight here in your quarters, what is it like?"
Daci said:
"Cold pine, a single hue, different for a thousand years. ??
Country oldsters plucking blossoms, spring in ten thousands lands."
The Master said:
"Now as in the past, forever transcending the Perfect Wisdom state.
But the Three Mountains are locked away behind ten-thousandfold barriers."
Daci gave a shout.
The Master also gave a shout.
Daci said:
"What's that?"
The Master shook out his sleeves and left.
When the Master arrived at Huayan's place in Xingzhou,
Huayan was propped on his staff, bent over as though sleeping.
The Master said:
"Old Reverend, what do you mean by dozing?"
Huayan siad:
"A first-rate Chan man is obviously not the same as others."
The Master said:
"Attendent, make some tea and bring it for the Reverend to drink."
Huayan then summoned the weina:
"See that this gentleman is seated in the third seat." [Provide the first seat on the third row]
When the Master arrived at Cuifeng's place,
Cuifeng asked:
"Where did you come from?"
"From Huangbo."
the Master said.
Cuifeng said:
"What words and phrases does Huangbo use to instruct people."
The Master said:
"Huangbo has no words or phrases."
Cuifeng said:
"Why doesn't he have any?"
The Master said:
"Even if he had any, they wouldn't be the sort of thing to mention."
Cuifeng said:
"Try mentioning them anyway."
The Masters said:
"An arrow streaks through the western sky."
When the Master arrived at Xiangtian's place,
he asked:
"Not a common mortal, not a sage - please, Master, speak quickly!"
Xiangtian said:
"I am just as you see me."
The Master gave a shout and then said:
"All you bald-heads -7
what kind of food do you hope to find in a place like this?"
When the Master arrived at Minghua's place,
Minghua said:
Coming and going, coming and going - what is this all about?"
The master said:
"Just tramping around wearing out my straw sandals,"
Minghua said:
"In the end, what is it for?"
The Master said:
"This old man doesn't even know how to talk!" ?? (You, old fellow, do not even recognize a phrase [for teaching] [CA])
The Master went to see Fenglin.
On the way he met an old woman.
"Off somewhere?"
she asked.
"Off to Fenglin,"
the Master said.
The old woman said:
"I think you'll find that Fenglin isn't in right now." (Fenglin does not happen to be in [CA])
The Master said:
"Off somewhere?"
The old woman walked away.
The Master called after her.
She turned her head,
whereupon the Master walked away.

When the Master arrived at Jinniu's place,
Jinniu saw him coming,
placing his staff across his knees, sat down squarely in the middle of the gate.
The Master rapped with his hand three times on the staff
and then went off to the monks' hall and sat down in the number one seat.
Jinniu came to look at him and said:
"There are appropriate ceremonies to be observed when a guest and host meet.
Where did you come from, sir,
that you behave in this outrageous manner!"
The Master said:
"Old Reverend, what's that you say?"
Jinniu was about to open his mouth
when the Master struck him a blow.
Jinniu made as though he were falling down,
whereupon the Master struck him again.
Jinniu said:
"Today is not my day!"
Weishan asked Yangshan:
"With these two worthy old gentlemen,
was there any winning and losing, or wasn't there?"
Yangshan said:
"As for winning, they won all the way,
and as for losing, they lost all the way."
When the Master was about to pass away, he sat up straight in his seat and said:
"After I am gone, you must not destroy my True Dharma Eye!"
Sansheng came forward and said:
"Who would dare to destroy the Master's True Dharma Eye?"
The Master said:
"Afterward, if someone should ask you about it,

Sansheng gave a shout.
The Master said:
"Who knows? My True Dharma Eye
